awd_titl_txt: CC* Networking Infrastructure: Improving the University of the Virgin Islands’ Scientific Research Data Movement Infrastructure and Network Capacity
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

The University of the Virgin Islands (UVI), through its Information Services and Institutional Assessment department and in collaboration with Virgin Islands Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research, aims to upgrade campus network switching electronics, implementing a Science DMZ (a perimeter network), and providing training opportunities for undergraduate students. The project will deliver increased network capacity and redundancy required to enable the movement of scientific data to conduct various network-based research activities, permit advanced computing, and take advantage of public cloud computing and storage resources. These improvements will increase UVI’s ability to support ongoing scientific research and teaching and attract new researchers. 

Network switching upgrades from 10/100BASE transmission speeds to high performing multigigabit network switches allow for increased network capacity and redundancy required to enable the movement of scientific data to conduct various research activities, permit advanced computing, take advantage of public cloud computing and storage resources, and also support the Internet of Things (IoT). These network improvements will build upon past NSF cyberinfrastructure investments, support UVI-based marine and environmental research that informs federal and territorial natural resources managers focused on marine ecosystems health, increase data sharing between researchers and collaborators, and help to facilitate time-sensitive environmental monitoring and real-time model validation. UVI's Science DMZ will offer a network environment tailored to the needs of high-performance science applications, including large data transfers, remote experiment control, data visualization, and addresses network performance problems that occur when large research data sets traverse through firewalls. It also will enable faster processing of data for UVI’s collaborating partner, the National Radio Astronomy Observatory, a radio telescope facility used by the international scientific community. Additionally, computer science and computational biology undergraduate students from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM will be provided opportunities for hands-on training and work experience. This project has potential to facilitate professional development, help build high-demand technical capacity within the university and across the Territory, and make a sound and long-term investment in campus-wide research and education at UVI.

This project is funded through the collaborative efforts of the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure (OAC) and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
UVI, like many campuses, faces constant challenges across multiple levels of cyberinfrastructure while working to meet the needs of scientific research and education. This challenge goes far beyond the networking layer in capacity and services, and extends to computing, data services, secure and trustworthy systems, and especially human expertise, collaboration and knowledge sharing. In rural and remote island institutions, most of these challenges are exacerbated by supply chain issues, service and maintenance challenges in small remote tropical settings, and by local shortages in the technical talent available to meet local needs. The opportunity that this CC* award presented helped address several chronic needs on our campus.

UVI, being an emerging research institution with a high cost of living and limited amenities, struggles with recruitment and retention of STEM professionals, especially in highly competitive (with the private sector) fields like computer sciences and data management. Currently, most of UVI’s IT infrastructure employees are graduates of the University. Some start with the unit as student employees, while others apply with no knowledge of the internal operations of the unit. At this moment, 100% of technicians and network operations staff have attended UVI. It is therefore to the University and the component’s benefit to continue developing students. At the same time, IT networking staff received professional development training so they could train the students working on configuration, installation, and deployment. The CC* award allowed us to develop current university technical staff while providing a possible pipeline of new talent. This speaks to the broader impacts of this award.

It is also important to recognize that UVI is predominantly a commuter school. Consequently, faculty, staff, and students rely heavily on internet connectivity and robust network infrastructure to access university resources. The networking capacity improvements achieved with our CC* award allowed us to augment and support key research areas which speaks to the intellectual merit of our CC* award. For example, most of our marine and environmental research that informs federal and territorial natural resource managers and university partners focus on coral ecosystem health. With the faster transmission speeds for uploading and downloading data to and from the on-premise high capacity virtual and cloud-based research servers and storage, the data sharing between our researchers and their partners helped facilitate time-sensitive environmental monitoring and model validation in real-time- extremely important in years with high levels of coral bleaching due to unusually warm ocean temperatures.
